The Project assumes mainly that the economy of the Maldives will 
continue to grow and create new jobs. In addition, it assumes that: 
(i) employers  will  be  motivated  to  hire  more  skilled  Maldivian 
workers;  (ii) Maldivian  youths  will  actively  seek  employment, 
including in occupations other than white-collar, and seek training; 
and (iii) stakeholders will cooperate and coordinate in a timely and 
constructive manner. The proposed Project aims to mitigate these 
risks  by:  (i) developing  and  delivering  training  that  is  oriented

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

The Republic of the Maldives is a nation of over 270,000 people living on 199 islands in 
2. 
an  archipelago  820  kilometers  long  and  120  kilometers  wide.  As  of  2002,  almost  half  of  the 
population (46%) was less than 15 years old. Twenty-seven percent of the population live in the 
national capital island of Malé while the rest live on 198 inhabited islands. In addition there are 
87  tourist  resort  islands  that  are  annually  the  home  of  6,500  Maldivians,  3,400  expatriate 
workers, and over 450,000 foreign tourists. The Government is committed to sustainable human 
development, which is reflected in its allocation of 40% of public expenditures to social services 
in  2001.  The  human  development  index  for  the  Maldives  is  0.739,  ranking  it  77th  out  of  162 
countries,  and  the  gender  development  index,  at  0.735,  is  second  only  to  that  of  Sri  Lanka  in 
South Asia.2  
 
High and rising per capita income3 masks significant income disparities. According to the 
3. 
1998  Vulnerability  and  Poverty  Assessment,4  as many as 42% of Maldivians live on less than 
$1.17  per  day  while  22%  subsist  on  $0.83  per  day.  Income  disparities  between  Malé  and  the 
atolls are in the order of 2:1. Inequalities are more pronounced in access to social and physical 
infrastructure  and  services,  which  averaged  4:1.  This  is  a  challenge  that  the  Government  has 
sought  to  address  since  the  1970s,  which  today  has  resulted  in  policy  initiatives  to  develop 
growth  center  islands  in  five  regions  to  reduce  disparities  in  access to essential services. The 
Government,  with  assistance  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  is  developing  the 
Northern and Southern Development regions. 
 
4. 
In  2002,  the  three  largest  sectors  of  the  economy  were  tourism  (31%), transport and 
communications  (14%),  and  government  administration  (12%).  Fisheries  used  to  account  for 
around 7.8% of gross domestic product (GDP), but its share has declined to 7.1%; the related 
secondary  sector  activity,  fish  preparation,  accounts  for about 3.0% of GDP. The share of the 
social sectors—education, health, and social services—is slowly shrinking: from 2.6% in 1995, it 
was  2.0%  in  2002.  Commodity  exports  in  2002  were  mostly  marine  products  (62%). 
Dependence on tourism, primary exports, and expatriate workers, contributes to the economy’s 
high vulnerability to external shocks.  
 
5. 
Labor  Force.  According  to  the  2000  Population  and  Housing  Census  (Census),  only 
56% of working-age Maldivians were in the labor force,5 with about a third of them employed in

The  largest  employer  of  Maldivians  is  the  Government  and  government  companies,  mainly  in 
community,  social,  and  personal  services;  manufacturing;  hotels  and  restaurants;  and  fishing. 
Island women are mostly in community, social, and personal services, and manufacturing. Few 
women  are  employed  in  fishing,  or  in  hotels  and  restaurants.  The  Maldivian  labor  force  is 
significantly augmented by expatriate workers. The share of expatriate workers in the total labor 
force increased from 13% in 1990 (8,700 workers) to 24% in 2000 (30,664 workers). According 
to the 2000 Census, expatriates are mostly employed in unskilled (42%) and semiskilled (36%) 
occupations.  More  than  80%  are  employed  in  resorts,  construction,  business  activities, 
education,  apparel,  and  hotels  and  restaurants.  Most  of  the  expatriate  workers  are  from 
Bangladesh, India, and Sri Lanka. Expatriate remuneration packages include accommodations 
and once-a-year airfare to the home country. Even with extra benefits and expenses incurred by 
employers, expatriate workers in some categories receive about 80% to 85% of the Maldivians’ 
salary and benefits. The employment of large numbers of expatriate workers, in spite of the high 
levels  of  unemployment  and  underemployment,  implies  a  significant  wastage  of  the  Maldives’ 
human resources potential. A key reason for this anomaly is the dearth of adequately educated 
and trained Maldivians to meet the needs of employers and the reluctance of some Maldivians 
to engage in less skilled occupations. The ESTP addresses this issue and seeks to increase the 
number  of  Maldivians  in  the  labor  force  by  increasing  access  to  employment  oriented  skills 
training programs (see Appendix 1). 
 
6. 
Education.  In  the  Maldives,  public  education  is  tuition-free  for  primary  grades  1  to  7, 
lower secondary grades 8 to 10, and higher secondary grades 11 to 12. Appendix 2 discusses 
the education and skills training sectors. As of 2000, all children in the Maldives have access to 
the first 7 years of formal schooling, one of the landmark achievements of the country. The adult 
literacy rate is 99%.  The cost of providing education in the Maldives remains high as students 
are scattered over 199  islands. However, high priority is placed on investing in education such 
that  the  education  budget  represents  20%  of  the  total  government  budgetary  expenditure.  In 
2002, there were 68,242 students enrolled in the primary grades, 23,903 in the lower secondary 
grades, and 1,131 in the higher secondary grades. In 2000, there were 452 primary schools, 74 
lower secondary schools, and 2 higher secondary schools. Efforts are under way to improve the 
quality of primary education by providing teacher training.   
 
7. 
Secondary  Education.  For  2002,  enrollment  data  for  grade  8  indicate  that  5,350 
students  or  36%  of  those  enrolled  in  grade  7  the  previous  year  in  primary  schools  did  not 
continue  on  to  secondary  schooling.  The  transition  rate  is  particularly  low  in  the  atolls. 
Admission  to  secondary  school  requires  successful  completion  of  grade  7;  however,  limited 
capacity  in  public  secondary  schools  has  necessitated  the  introduction  of  selection  processes 
for  admission.  Despite  ongoing  efforts  to  increase  access  to  secondary  education,  geographic 
conditions still limit access to secondary education as the majority of schools are located in atoll 
capitals and on larger islands of high population. At the end of grade 10, students typically take 
Ordinary-level  (O-level)  examinations.  The  pass  rate  in  most  subjects,  including  English, 
mathematics, and the sciences, is below 50%.8 Among those with O-level qualifications, few are 
able to go to higher secondary school. As of 2002, there were only four schools offering higher

8. 
Skills  Training.  Access  to  preemployment  skills  training  through  public  and  private 
providers is limited. Skills training in the Maldives is provided mainly by the Maldives College of 
Higher  Education  (MCHE)  through  its  various  faculties,  including  the  Faculty  of  Engineering 
Technology  (FET),  Faculty  of  Hospitality  and  Tourism  Studies  (FHTS),  and  the  Center  for 
Maritime  Studies  (CMS).  In  2002,  CMS  dominated  MCHE  short-course  enrollment  with  2,103 
students, or 82.1% of all MCHE short-course skills training. Maritime training is male-dominated, 
with  no  female  trainees  enrolled.  Enrollment  in  entry-level  employment  skills  training  through 
short-courses offered by MCHE faculties other than CMS progressively declined from 2,839 in 
1998 to 818 in 2002. Trainees enrolled in short-term training pay fees that may cover learning 
materials  and  training  delivery  costs.  In  recent  months,  MCHE  has  received  an  increasing 
number of requests from atoll chiefs for short-term skills training that could be provided by FHTS 
and FET;  however,  many  of  these  requests  cannot  be  met  within  their  respective  budgets. 
MCHE  is  presently  receiving  ADB  assistance  focused  on  developing  diploma  and  advanced 
certificate courses through faculty development and course reviews, and program accreditation.  
 
9. 
The  Ministry  of  Education  (MOE)  coordinates  and  implements  nonformal  education 
programs  in  the  Maldives.  Through  the  Center  for  Continuing  Education,  MOE  provides  basic 
education  for  adults.  Formerly  known  as  the  Non-Formal  Education  Center,  the  Center  for 
Continuing Education provides courses for adults to complete primary school, improve English 
language courses, and offered some courses such as secretarial skills development, training in 
early  childhood  care  and  development, population education, and community awareness. The 
Ministry  of  Fisheries,  Agriculture  and  Marine  Resources  conducts  agriculture-  and  fisheries-
related  skills  training.  The  Ministry  of  Youth  and  Sports  (MYS)  offers  a  variety  of  training 
activities for youths. In addition to offering sports and recreational programs in its youth centers, 
MYS  provides  training  in  sports-coaching,  dressmaking,  and  hairdressing.  The  Ministry  of 
Human  Resources,  Employment  and  Labor  (MHREL)  has  initiated  a  skills  development loan 
scheme to fund specialized training, such as Scuba dive master instruction. 
 
In  2002,  66  private  training  providers  were  registered  with  MOE.9  Eighty-five  percent 
10. 
offer computer instruction and approximately half are located in Malé. Accurate enrollment data 
on  trainees  are  not  available.  In  addition  to  private  education  and  training  firms,  many 
employers  provide  in-house  training  programs  and  courses  for  their  employees.  Larger  firms 
provide  scholarships  and  support  the  education  and  professional  development  of  employees. 
The contribution of private enterprise to skills training is significant; however, no qualitative and 
quantitative  data  are  available  on  the  number  of  trainees  or  financial  investment  in  on-the-job 
training and professional development.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities  

13. 
National  economic  development  requires  the  efficient  employment  of  all  available 
resources,  including  human  resources.  The  Maldives’  failure  to  adequately  utilize  its  human 
resources potential is a key constraint to development. Increasing the employment of Maldivians 
would  promote  more  equitable  sharing  of  the  benefits  of  economic  development,  and  is  a 
sustainable  approach  to  poverty  reduction.  While  the  Maldives’  economy  grew  at  annual 
average of about 8%11 between 1995 and 2000,12 the labor force expanded by only 5%. During 
the  same  period,  expatriate  labor  grew  at  an  annual  average  of  8%.  The  Maldives  is  highly 
dependent  on  skilled  expatriate  labor.  Employers,  including  the  Government,  hire  expatriate 
workers  in  the  absence  of  properly  trained  and  qualified  Maldivians.  This  is  against  the 
backdrop  of  untapped  human  resources,  which  include  a  large  number  of  youths  who  are 
outside the labor force. An increasing number of youths have completed primary education but 
could not continue on to further education. These young men and women are capable but have 
limited  access  to  skills  training  programs.  In  2000,  there  were  25,461  youths  aged  15  to  19 
(77% of the cohort) who were not in the labor force. To make better use of its human resources 
potential, the Maldives must (i) make the prospective Maldivian employee more attractive to the 
employer, and (ii) make training and employment more attractive to the Maldivian employee.    
 
 
14. 
Prospective employees will be more attractive to employers if they are better trained and 
qualified  in  needed  occupational  areas.  For  training  to  be  more  attractive  to  Maldivian  youths, 
access to high-quality skills training programs must be increased, the training programs offered 
must  offer  a  high  likelihood  of  employment,  and  the  training  offered  should  be  in  occupations 
attractive  to  the  trainee.  Employment  will  be  more  attractive  when  work  conditions,  including 
work  hours,  leave,  and  accommodation,  are  appropriate.  Employment  regulations  have  to  be 
effectively monitored to ensure that employees’ and employers’ rights are not transgressed. The 
key issues thus relate to the availability of skills training opportunities, demand for skills training, 
quality and relevance of skills training, and the work environment.

Project Benefits and Impacts 

61. 
Economic Benefits. With about half of Maldivians not in the labor force, the economic 
growth of  the  Maldives  has  been  aided  by  the  employment  of  expatriate  workers.  The  Project 
will generate increases in labor productivity that will increase the competitiveness of Maldivians 
in the labor market. Coupled with MHREL’s increased capacity to monitor and  implement labor 
regulations and perform labor market analysis, the above activities will lead to the employment 
of more Maldivians in current and future positions that may be presently and/or expected to be 
held by expatriates. In addition, employment of more Maldivians will contribute to the retention 
of more foreign exchange. 
 
62. 
Through  the  Project’s  various  components,  the  matching  of  labor  supply  with  labor 
demand  will  improve.  The  involvement  of  the  private  sector,  the  Government,  and  skills 
practitioners in determining the human resource needs in the selected sectors and in developing 
needed training programs will yield good quality labor market information and more appropriate 
training  programs.  MHREL’s  increased  capacity  to  analyze  labor  market  data  will  enable  it  to 
give  timely  guidance  on  the  changing  needs  of  the  labor  market.  MNET’s  establishment  will 
contribute  to  facilitating  and  coordinating  the  different  stakeholders  and  requirements  for 
training.  The  wider  dissemination  of  information  on  employment  opportunities  will  reduce  the 
search time for both employees and employers. 
 
63. 
About  6,000  youths  will  receive  employment-oriented skills training through the Project 
that  meets  employers’  requirements.  Where  half  of  the  trainees  would  find  employment  for  at 
least 5 years and earn on average Rf2,000 per month, the project investment would be justified, 
with  an  indicative  economic  rate  of  return  of  33%.  See  Appendix  12  for  the  economic  and 
financial  analysis.  Without  the  project,  the  Maldives  will  continue  to  repatriate  increasing 
amounts of foreign exchange for the increasing number of expatriate workers it needs for further 
economic development, representing forgone income that could be shared by local Maldivians 
and used for further development activities.

the  different  employment  stakeholders  that  would  lead  to  greater  coordination  of  activities,

will  facilitate  the  coordination  of  training  requirements  and  training  provision.  Increasing  the 
domestic  capacity  at  MCHE  and  MOE  to  design  skills  training  programs  and  develop  related 
instructional materials will contribute to: (i) increasing the range of skills training programs that

competency  framework  and  skills  standards  will  provide  the  framework  for  designing  and

1. 
 Between  1995  and  2000,  the  Maldives’  economy  grew  at  the  average  annual  rate  of 
about 8%.1 During the same time period, the Maldivian labor force grew annually at the average 
of  5.3%  annually  while  expatriate  labor  grew  by  8.1%.2  The  Maldives  is  highly  dependent  on 
skilled  expatriate  labor.  Employers,  including  the  Government,  hire  expatriate  workers  in  the 
absence of properly trained and qualified Maldivians. This is against the backdrop of  untapped 
human  resources,  which  includes  the  large  number  of  youths  who  are  not  in  the  labor  force; 
have  completed  primary  education  but  could  not  continue  on  to  further  education;  and  are 
capable  but  have  limited  access  to  skills  training  programs.  In  2000,  there  were  over  25,000 
youths aged 15 to 19 (77% of the cohort)3 who were not in the labor force and over 21,000 of 
those  aged  20  to  34.  In  this  connection,  the  Maldives  faces  the  challenges  of  (i) making the 
prospective  Maldivian  employee  more  attractive  to  the  employer,  and  (ii) making  training  and 
employment more attractive to the Maldivian employee.   
 
2. 
Labor Force.  According  to  the  2000  Population  and  Housing  Census  (Census),  only 
56%  of  working-age  Maldivians  were  in  the  labor  force4  and  about  a  third  of  them  were 
employed  in  Malé;  in  addition,  there  were  about  30,664  foreign  workers,  comprising 
approximately 24% of the total labor force.5 In 1990, there were only 8,700 expatriate workers or 
13% of the labor force. Repatriation of wages contributes significantly to the outflow of foreign 
exchange. A large number of expatriate jobs could eventually be filled by qualified Maldivians if 
(i) employment-oriented  education  and  training  programs  were  available;  (ii) a  systemic 
approach was used to coordinate resources and stakeholders in labor supply and employment 
demand; and (iii) labor regulations were effectively implemented to ensure equal and equitable 
working conditions, wages and benefits for women and men, Maldivians and expatriates. 
 
3.

occupations.  More  than  80%  were  employed  in  resorts,  construction,  business  activities,

the  expansion  of  secondary  education  and  improving  the  quality  of  education.  Free,  public 
education in the Maldives comprises 12 grades. Primary education is from grades 1 to 7, lower 
secondary education is grades 8 to 10, and higher secondary education is grades 11 to 12.

upgraded  to  secondary  schools.  From  29  schools  offering  secondary  education  in  1995,  there 
were  74  in  2000.  Regardless,  the  number  of  youths  unable  to  go  on  beyond  grade  7  to

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 

Economic Analysis 

 
A. 
 
The Maldives’ economy grew at an annual average of 8%, in real terms, between 1995 
1. 
and 2000. During the same time period, the number of Maldivians in the labor force grew by 5% 
annually  while  the  number  of  expatriate  workers  increased  8%  per  year.  The  economy  of  the 
Maldives is expected to continue growing. Between 2004 and 2007, annual real gross domestic 
product  growth  is  forecast  to  average  between  6.2%  and  2.6%.  As  the  economy  continues  to 
expand,  more  trained  people  will  be  required;  in  the  absence  of  locally  available  qualified  and 
trained  labor,  expatriate  workers  are  hired  to  fill  the  gap.  This  is  against  the  backdrop  of 
untapped human resources, i.e., the large number of youths who are not in the labor force, who 
have completed primary education but could not continue on to further education, and who are 
capable but have limited access to skills training programs. Additionally, the Maldives is already 
heavily  dependent  on  imported  merchandise,  and  the  employment  of  expatriate  workers 
contributes to the further deterioration of its current account balance.   
 
2. 
Government  intervention  in  skills  training,  either  in  provision  and/or  financing,  is 
rationalized  on  the  grounds  of  market  imperfections,  externalities,  and  equity.1  Public  policy, 
e.g.,  employment  regulations,  may  unintentionally  distort  the  cost  and  benefit  stream  of  skills 
training such that less training than required by economic development would take place. The 
availability  of  skilled  labor  would  contribute  to  meeting  the  macroeconomic  goals  of  a  country, 
notably  addressing  balance-of-payments  problems  and  retention  of  foreign  exchange  and 
availability of semi-skilled human resources.     
 
3. 
The  Project  will  focus  on  delivering  training  in  four  key  sectors—tourism, fisheries and 
agriculture,  transport,  and  the  social  sectors—that  are  included  in  the  national  development 
priority and play an important role in the continued economic well-being of the country. Tourism 
is mainly a private sector activity, a major employment sector, and the major source of foreign 
exchange revenue. Tourism also employs many expatriate workers, ranging from the skilled to 
the unskilled. In the fisheries sector, two fishing zones have been opened up for private sector 
investment and will require more workers in the near future. The development of agriculture is 
important to national food security. Transportation is an extremely important and growing sector 
supporting both tourism and the fisheries. An international airport will soon be operational in the 
southern region. The social sector, consisting primarily of education and health, is critical to the 
well-being of the population and is currently heavily reliant on expatriate employment. 
 
4. 
The  economic  justification  of  the  Project  derives  mainly  from  increased  access  to 
training programs that are relevant to the needs of the labor market. About  6,000 trainees will 
be  trained  during  the  life  of  the  Project  by  supporting  the  development  and  delivery  of  more 
training  programs  that  are  employment-oriented  and  are  competency-based  in  the  four  key 
sectors.  Depending  on  trainees’  capacity  to  pay,  the  demand  for  the  training  program, 
employment  prospects,  and  the  remuneration  of  related  jobs,  students  may  be  requested  to 
share in the costs. Fees are already being charged for some short-term courses at the Maldives 
College  of  Higher  Education  faculties  and  center  to  cover  learning  materials  and/or  training 
delivery  costs.  Trainees  may  also  incur  out-of-pocket  costs  to  pay  for  their  transportation, 
subsistence,  and  accommodation,  where  applicable.  Trainees  will  mostly  be  drawn  from  the

Indicative Economic Rate of Return. The Project’s indicative economic rate of return is 
33%.  The  main  beneficiaries  of  the  Project  are  the  unemployed  out-of-school  youths.  The

employment  in  the  year  following  the  completion  of  their  training.  As  the  economy  of  the 
Maldives  diversifies  and  more  jobs  are  created,  trainees  may  want  to  re-train  and  switch 
occupations  to  earn  higher  salaries  or  work  in  islands  closer  to  their  home-islands;  thus, 
trainees  are  assumed  to  be  in  the  training-program-related employment for 5 years. Trainees’ 
monthly  salary  is  assumed  at  Rf2,000  per  month.  Sample  salary  data  collected  during  project 
preparatory  technical  assistance  from  the  tourism  sector  indicate  that waiters earn Rf1,200 to 
Rf2,000, and maintenance personnel, Rf1,500 to Rf4,000. Trainees’ out-of-pocket training costs 
are  estimated  at  Rf1,500  per  month,  which  includes  transportation,  accommodation,  and 
subsistence  that  may  likely  be  incurred  if  training  were  offered  in  another  island.  The  average 
length of training programs is about 3 months. The discount rate is 12%. Sensitivity was tested 
by increasing costs and benefits by 20%; the Project remains economically justified under these 
conditions.

The Government’s share in the project is estimated at $1.5 million over 5 years and will 
consist mainly of the incremental recurrent cost of $1.0 million and share in special programs of 
$0.3 million. Two scenarios were prepared to analyze its affordability (i) a “high” scenario where 
the  education  budget  was  projected  based  on  the  actual  expenditure  from  1995  to  2001;  and 
(ii) a  “low”  scenario  where  the  education  budget  remains  the  same  from  2002  onward.  Under 
both  scenarios,  the  Government’s  share  in  the  both  the  project  and  recurrent  costs  are 
affordable. 
 
8. 
The  annual  share  of  the  Government  in  the  project  cost  was  compared  to  the  annual 
education budget (high scenario) for the years 2004 to 2009. The Government’s annual share 
as a percentage of the education budget ranges from 0.3% to 0.6%, averaging 0.5% over the 5-
year life of the Project. The Government’s share in the recurrent cost was also compared to the 
education recurrent budget for 2004 to 2009. The Government’s share as a percentage of the 
education  recurrent  budget  averaged  0.3%  over  the  life  of  the  project.  From  the  sixth  year 
onward,  after  the  project  implementation  has  ended,  the  Government  will  assume  about 
$97,000 annually for the incremental recurrent cost, which will have to be incurred as a result of 
project interventions. This amount is only 0.2% of the projected education recurrent budget for 
that  year.  Hence  the  Government  share  in  both  the  project  and  recurrent  cost  are  deemed 
affordable.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the Maldives: 
 
The Project aims to increase the number of skilled Maldivians participating in the labor force and who will 
be  attractive  to  local  employers  by  increasing  access  to  quality  employment-oriented  skills  training 
programs,  among  others.  Participation  of  Maldivians  in  the  economic  development  process  by  being 
employed  allows  for  their  sharing  in  the  benefits  of  economic  growth.  Employment  is  a  sustainable 
approach to poverty reduction. Training programs supported by the Project will be offered not only in Malé 
and adjacent atolls but also in islands in the Northern and Southern Development regions where the more 
vulnerable Maldivians live. 

B. 

Poverty Analysis                                                     Proposed Classification Poverty Intervention 

 
The Mission relied on statistics, studies, and reports by the Government, Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
United  Nations  Development  Program  (UNDP),  and  the  World  Bank.  Relevant  statistics  were  analyzed 
from  the  2000  Population  and  Housing  Census  data  of  the  Government.  ADB  published  Poverty 
Reduction  in  the  Maldives  in  2002  and  the  Maldives  Gender  Briefing  Paper,  and  UNDP  produced 
Vulnerability  and  Poverty  Assessment  1998.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  team  also 
collected  information  through  the  focus  group  discussions  and  participatory  workshops  held  in  various 
islands in the country. 

The human development index for Maldives in 2001 is 0.739, ranking it 77th out of  162 countries, and the 
gender development index, at 0.735, is second only to that of Sri Lanka in South Asia. 1 High and rising per 
capita income masks significant income disparities among the 270,000 Maldivians. The 1998 vulnerability 
and  poverty  assessment  (VPA)2  estimated  per  capita  household  income  for  the  atoll  population  at  only 
$647 per year. As many as 42% of Maldivians live on less than $1.17 per day while 22% subsist on $0.83 
per  day.  Significant  differences  exist  between  Malé  and  the  atolls  in  terms  of  access  to  services  and 
infrastructure,  including  health,  sanitation,  water,  and  education.  Some  islands  have  made  considerable 
strides  because  of  their  close  proximity  to  tourism  zones.  Other  islands  have  no  such  advantage  and  are 
barely accessible. Taking income as an example, disparities between Malé and the atolls have been found 
to  be  in  the  order  of  2:1,  with  the  ratio  increasing  to  3:1  when  the  lowest  average  per  capita  income  was 
considered.  For  access  to  social  and  physical  infrastructure  and  services,  inequalities  are  far  more 
pronounced,  averaging  4:1  between  the  capital  and  the  atolls.  This  is  a  challenge  that  the  Government 
has  sought  to  address  since  the  1970s,  which  today  has  resulted  in  policy  initiatives  to  develop  growth 
center  islands  in  five  regions  to  reduce  disparities  in  access  to  essential  services  between  Malé  and  the 
atolls.  The  Project  builds  on  the  ongoing  ADB-financed  Regional  Development  Project  by  including  its 
focus regions in the Project’s focus regions. Training programs will be offered not only in Malé but also in 
the  islands.  Community  training  initiatives  will  address  the  needs  of  the  smaller  islands  that  have  less 
access to training programs and formal employment.

The Government is committed to increasing the role of women in the society and economy. Vision 2020 of

including  in  education  and  health  servi ces. However, women’s labor force participation rate (32%) is less
